question: A 42  year old illiterate lady presented with tachycardia, increased sweating, palpitations, heat intolerance and weight loss despite an increased appetite. An error had been made by a pharmacy technician while dispensing her oral contraceptive pills a month earlier - she was given L-thyroxine instead. Which of the following is most correct about her condition?
options: Her serum TSH, T4 and T3 are low
She suffers from iatrogenic or factitious hyperthyroidism
Long term oral contraceptive use can explain her condition
This is and adverse drug reaction
answer: She suffers from iatrogenic or factitious hyperthyroidism

question: A 42 year old cancer patient presents in the Emergency Room semi-conscious and disoriented. His pulse and blood pressure are 140/80mmHg and 94 beats per minute respectively, and his body temperature is 37.5⁰C. He has no peripheral oedema. Serum electrolytes and urea reveal sodium to be 125mMol/L. A cranial computed tomography scan reveals cerebral oedema. In which organ is his primary tumour most likely to be?

A 30 year old female presents with skin, soft tissue and visceral enlargement, menstrual disturbances, hypertension and a diabetic range plasma glucose upon administration of an oral glucose load. Which of the following is in excess?
A 35 year old female presents to the clinic with features of Weight loss, increased appetite, increased sweating, tachycardia and palpitations. The most likely diagnosis is
Cortisol is synthesized mainly in the
options: Zonal fasciculata of the adrenal cortex
Zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex
answer: Zonal fasciculata of the adrenal cortex

question: Polyuria, nocturia and hyposthenuria are typical features of the following renal diseases

A 4 year old boy presented with frothy urine few weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection. Light microscopy of the renal biopsy showed no relevant pathological findings and Electron microscopy showed effacement of the foot processes. Immunofluorescence is likely to show
options: Strong linear IgG stain on glomerular capillary wall(GCW)
Dominant IgA stain in the mesangial area
Granular IgM stain in the glomerular capillary wall

question: The following renal lesions are associated with interstitial foam cells

A 6 year old child presented with purpuric skin rash, hematuria and proteinuria. Light microscopy showed mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis. Immunofluorescence revealed strong granular IgA and IgG staining in the GCW. EM revealed mesangial deposits. What is the most plausible diagnosis,
Tubulorecticular inclusions are seen in the following renal diseases
Papillary necrosis can be seen in which of the following renal conditions

A 35 year old female with a chronic history of severe dysmenorrhea. One of her coping strategies was to be on analgesic cocktail, mostly mixtures of 2 or 3 and occasionally of a single type. She recently came down with a renal disease with complaints of nocturia, hypertension and polyuria. What is the limit of the drug dosage to a renal disease and over what period
Morphology of the Kidneys in Analgesic Nephropathy
options: Mesangial immune deposits on electron microscopy
Dominant IgA and IgG stain on immunofluorescence stain

question: Nephropathy associated with NSAIDs include
About lupus nephritis
options: Renal biopsy is needed for diagnosis
Effacement of foot processes is a common feature
Electron dense deposits are only intramembranous
Immunofluorescence is strongly positive for only IgM
Mesangioproliferative GN is a possible picture on light microscopy
answer: Mesangioproliferative GN is a possible picture on light microscopy

question: A 40 year old man presented with anasarca, hematuria, proteinuria and oliguria. Light microscopy showed glomeruli with endocapillary and mesangial hypercellularity. EM revealed subendothelial deposits. Which of the following is true about this case
options: Minimal change disease Is the most likely diagnosis
It is a case of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
The features are those of a typical Nephrotic syndrome
The features are those of a typical Nephritic syndrome
This is a case of Fabry's disease
answer: It is a case of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

question: About Membranoproliferative GN
options: It is also known as Lipoid Nephritis
Morphology may be normal on light microscopy
The type II is known as dense deposit disease
Only the alternate complement pathway is activated in the type I
Typical appearance on JMS is the presence of spikes
answer: The type II is known as dense deposit disease

question: A 50 year old Engineer came down with left flank mass, weight loss and hematuria. Histology of a biopsy sample showed renal cell carcinoma. What is/are the risk factor(s)?
Morphological variants of Renal Cell Carcinoma include;
Presence of interstitial forms cells with non-nephrotic range proteinuria is suggestive of
The clinical features of a typical Nephrotic syndrome include;
Typical features of Nephritic syndrome include
About Polycystic kidney disease
options: It is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease
They all have autosomal dominant mode of inheritance
They all have autosomal recessive mode of inheritance

question: The major glasses of thrombotic microangiopathies(TMAs) are
The following immune on EM matches their Iomerular lesions correctly;
options: Mesangial deposit and Minimal change disease

question: Neurons react to injury through the following means
Morphology of cerebral oedema
explanation: Flattened gyri and narrow sulci in cerebral oedema

question: Which ofthe following statements are true
options: Astrocytes are responsible for tissue repair in the CNS
The ventricular surfaces are lined by astrocytes
Neuron Specific Enolase is a marker for glial cells
answer: Neuron Specific Enolase is a marker for glial cells
explanation: marker for glial cells NSe, Niphphysin and n

question: Reaction of astrocytes to injury include

options: Cytoplasmic complex lipids and Tay-Sachs disease
answer: Cytoplasmic complex lipids and Tay-Sachs disease

question: Which of these is not a form of brain herniations
Forebrain anomalies include
About hemorrhages in the CNS
options: Epidural hematoma is due to rupture of bridging veins
Subdural hematoma is often due to rupture of middle meningeal artery
Subdural hematoma is often due to rupture of bridging veins
Subdural hematoma is uncommon in the elderly
answer: Subdural hematoma is often due to rupture of bridging veins

question: More about heamorrhages in the CNS
options: Subgaleal hematoma occurs just above the scalp aponeurosis
Subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly due to systemic hypertension
Subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly due to rupture of berry aneurysms
Intraparenchymal hemorrhage may be a feature of concussion
answer: Subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly due to rupture of berry aneurysms

question: Which of thee is not a component of hypertensive cerebrovascular disease
The following are sequelae of CNS infections except
HIV neuropathy includes the following except
Alzheimer's disease
options: Impairs higher intellectual function with alterations in mood and behavior
Typically symptomatic before 50 years, incidence rises with age
Pathologic examination of brain tissue is optional for definitive diagnosis
answer: Impairs higher intellectual function with alterations in mood and behavior

question: Concerning CNS tumors
options: Intra-spinal tumors are most common than intracranial tumors
Most childhood tumors arise in the posterior fossa
Most adult tumors arise in the posterior fossa
answer: Most childhood tumors arise in the posterior fossa

question: WHO grading of CNS tumors
options: Most meningioma are WHO grade I/IV
Papillary and Rhabdoid Meningioma are WHO grade II/IV
Pilocytic Astrocytoma is WHO grade II/IV
Embryonal tumors e.g. Medulloblastomas are WHO grade II/IV
answer: Most meningioma are WHO grade I/IV

question: CNS tumors are different from tumors of other organs because
options: There is a clear distinction between benign and malignant lesions.
Tumors at certain sites can fatal of the tumor type
Surgical resection without compromise of neurologic function is easily done.
answer: Tumors at certain sites can fatal of the tumor type

question: Global cerebral ischemia
options: Is reduction in blood flow to a part of the brain due to vessel occlusion
Clinical outcome is the same irrespective of severity Of insult

question: A 30 year old male died within 24 hours of arrival at the emergency unit with a presumed diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. At autopsy he had extensive purulent exudates at the base of the brain. What are the likely causative pathogens?
explanation: In adolescents and young adults, Nisseria meningitides is the commonest agent followed by Haemophilus influenzae. Patients present with signs of meningeal irritation such as headache, photophobia, irritability, neck stiffness and altered consciousness.Mortality can be reduced by effective Antibiotic agents. Untreated cases may be fatal.

question: The following CNS disorders are caused by protein misfolding
Concerning hydrocephalus:
options: There is compensatory enlargement of the ventricles in response to loss of brain tissue In hydrocephalus ex vacuo
Stenosis of aqueduct of Sylvius results in communicating hydrocephalus
Hydrocephalus ex vacuo is commonly seen in infants
answer: There is compensatory enlargement of the ventricles in response to loss of brain tissue In hydrocephalus ex vacuo

question: The most common haemodynamic mechanism of pulmonary oedema is
The mediastinum in obstructive atelectasis shifts towards
options: Either side depending on the cause
The opposite side if it is cause by tuberculosis
explanation:
Resuptive/Obstructive: mediastium push to the affected side 
compressive ateletasis : pushes mediastinum to opposite
Obstructive Fibrosis and the lungs colapse to the affected side

question: In bronchial asthma there is
The main source of injury in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is
Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome in not seen in one of those conditions
Acute cor pulmonale can occur because of
Heart failure cells are
options: Type II pneumocytes that produce lung surfactant
Necrotic cells that are responsible for heart failure
Macrophages that are laden with haemosiderin in chronic pulmonary congestion
Swollen myocardial cells in heart failure
answer: Macrophages that are laden with haemosiderin in chronic pulmonary congestion

question: Brown induration of the lung is seen in
Wedge-shape shadow on chest X ray indicates

question: Earliest Features of chronic bronchitis
options: Goblet cells increase in small airways
Hypersecretion of mucus in large airways

answer: Hypersecretion of mucus in large airways

question: The ratio of relative thickness of mucus gland layer with the thickness of the wall between the epithelium and cartilage in the bronchi is called

options: White cell exudation into the alveoli
Enzymatic digestion of the alveolar exudates
The cut surface resembles the cut surface of liver
answer: Enzymatic digestion of the alveolar exudates

What is the best description of Eisenmenger's syndrome?
options: It occurs when a right to left shunt becomes left to right due to build-up of pressure in the left side of the heart
It results from failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral
A component of tetralogy of Fallot
An initial left to right shunt becomes right to left due to increased pulmonary blood flow and eventual right ventricular hypertrophy
Claudication resulting from coarctation of the aorta
answer: An initial left to right shunt becomes right to left due to increased pulmonary blood flow and eventual right ventricular hypertrophy

Reduction in the left ventricular cavity
